title: Proverbs Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Proverbs chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Proverbs Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Proverbs Chapter 17.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:1, what is better than a house full of sacrifices with strife?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:1 states that better is a dry morsel and quietness therewith than a house full of sacrifices with strife, emphasizing peace over abundance.

questions.question: Who shall have rule over a son that causes shame according to Proverbs 17:2?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:2 says a wise servant shall have rule over a son that causeth shame, indicating wisdom over birthright in this case.

questions.question: What does the LORD try according to Proverbs 17:3?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:3 explains that just as silver and gold are refined by fire, the LORD trieth the hearts, meaning God tests the inner character.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:5, who does one mock when they mock the poor?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:5 states that whoso mocketh the poor reproacheth his Maker, showing that mocking the poor is an insult to God.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:6, what are children's children called?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:6 refers to grandchildren as the crown of old men, symbolizing honor and pride.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 17:7 says excellent speech becometh a fool.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:7 states that excellent speech becometh not a fool, meaning fools do not suitably use excellent speech.

questions.question: What is a gift compared to in Proverbs 17:8?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:8 compares a gift to a precious stone in the eyes of the recipient, highlighting its value.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:9, what does he that covereth a transgression seek?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:9 explains that covering a transgression seeks love, whereas repeating it separates friends.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:10, into whom does a reproof enter more?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:10 says a reproof enters more into a wise man than a hundred stripes into a fool, indicating the wise accept correction.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 17:11 says an evil man seeketh only peace.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:11 states an evil man seeketh only rebellion, not peace, and therefore a cruel messenger is sent against him.

questions.question: In Proverbs 17:14, what is the beginning of strife compared to?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:14 compares the beginning of strife to letting out water, which is hard to stop once started.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 17:17 says a friend loveth at all times.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:17 clearly states that a friend loves at all times, showing steadfast friendship.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Proverbs 17:22: 'A merry heart doeth good like a ______.'
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:22 says a merry heart doeth good like a medicine, indicating joy's healing power.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:23, what does a wicked man take out of the bosom?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:23 states a wicked man taketh a gift out of the bosom to pervert judgment, showing corruption.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:28, when is a fool counted wise?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:28 says even a fool, when he holds his peace, is counted wise, highlighting the value of silence.

medium.title: Proverbs Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Proverbs Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with family conflict and asks for advice on how to find peace at home. Based on Proverbs 17, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Better is a dry morsel with quietness than a house full of sacrifices with strife.
A wise servant shall have rule over a son that causeth shame.
He that rewardeth evil for good shall not depart from his house.
The beginning of strife is like letting out water.
questions.correctAnswer: Better is a dry morsel with quietness than a house full of sacrifices with strife.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:1 teaches that peace and quietness are more valuable than abundance accompanied by conflict. This encourages believers to prioritize harmony in family life. Related verses include Proverbs 17:14 which warns that strife should be stopped early, and Proverbs 17:19 which links loving strife to destruction.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 17:3 illustrate God's role in spiritual discipline and personal growth?
options: The LORD trieth the hearts like a fining pot for silver and furnace for gold.
A wise servant shall have rule over a son that causeth shame.
He that covereth a transgression seeketh love.
A friend loveth at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD trieth the hearts like a fining pot for silver and furnace for gold.
questions.explanation: This verse shows that just as metals are refined by fire, God tests and purifies the hearts of believers. This teaches the importance of trusting God's refining process in trials (Proverbs 17:3), supported by the idea of perseverance in adversity in Proverbs 17:17.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to mock or look down on the poor. According to Proverbs 17, what is the spiritual consequence of this behavior?
options: Whoso mocketh the poor reproacheth his Maker and shall not be unpunished.
Better is a dry morsel with quietness than a house full of sacrifices with strife.
He that hath knowledge spareth his words.
A gift is as a precious stone in the eyes of him that hath it.
questions.correctAnswer: Whoso mocketh the poor reproacheth his Maker and shall not be unpunished.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:5 teaches that mocking the poor is ultimately an insult to God who made them, and such behavior brings punishment. This highlights the call to humility and respect for others (Proverbs 17:5), also echoed in Proverbs 17:23 about justice and gifts.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 17:9 guide believers in handling offenses and promoting reconciliation?
options: He that covereth a transgression seeketh love; but he that repeateth a matter separateth very friends.
A reproof entereth more into a wise man than an hundred stripes into a fool.
He that rewardeth evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.
A friend loveth at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
questions.correctAnswer: He that covereth a transgression seeketh love; but he that repeateth a matter separateth very friends.
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes forgiveness and the importance of not spreading offenses to maintain friendship and love. It teaches forgiveness and discretion (Proverbs 17:9), in harmony with Proverbs 17:14 about avoiding contention and Proverbs 17:10 about wise acceptance of correction.

questions.question: A church member is struggling to accept correction. Based on Proverbs 17, what biblical principle would you share about receiving reproof?
options: A reproof entereth more into a wise man than an hundred stripes into a fool.
He that hath knowledge spareth his words.
A gift is as a precious stone in the eyes of him that hath it.
questions.correctAnswer: A reproof entereth more into a wise man than an hundred stripes into a fool.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:10 teaches that wise people learn and grow from correction, whereas fools resist it. This encourages humility and a teachable spirit, consistent with Proverbs 17:27 on sparing words and understanding.

questions.question: True or False: According to Proverbs 17:17, a true friend only loves you in good times but may abandon you in adversity.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:17 states that a friend loves at all times and a brother is born for adversity, highlighting steadfast friendship. This teaches the Christian virtue of loyalty and support during trials.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:22, what is the effect of a merry heart compared to a broken spirit?
options: A merry heart doeth good like a medicine: but a broken spirit drieth the bones.
A wicked man taketh a gift to pervert judgment.
He that covereth a transgression seeketh love.
He that begetteth a fool doeth it to his sorrow.
questions.correctAnswer: A merry heart doeth good like a medicine: but a broken spirit drieth the bones.
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes the practical benefit of joy and a positive spirit for health and well-being, encouraging believers to cultivate a joyful heart and avoid despair (Proverbs 17:22).

questions.question: A believer considers paying a bribe to influence judgment. What does Proverbs 17 say about this practice?
options: A wicked man taketh a gift out of the bosom to pervert the ways of judgment.
Better is a dry morsel with quietness than a house full of sacrifices with strife.
A reproof entereth more into a wise man than an hundred stripes into a fool.
He that rewardeth evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.
questions.correctAnswer: A wicked man taketh a gift out of the bosom to pervert the ways of judgment.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:23 condemns taking bribes as corrupting justice. This teaches the importance of integrity and fairness in daily life (Proverbs 17:23), linked to honesty and wisdom in Proverbs 17:27.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted ____.', according to Proverbs 17.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:28 states that silence can give the appearance of wisdom, even in a fool, teaching the value of restraint in speech. This relates to the wisdom of sparing words in Proverbs 17:27.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 17:6 describe the relationship between generations in a family?
options: Children's children are the crown of old men; and the glory of children are their fathers.
A friend loveth at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
He that begetteth a fool doeth it to his sorrow.
A man void of understanding striketh hands in the presence of his friend.
questions.correctAnswer: Children's children are the crown of old men; and the glory of children are their fathers.
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the blessing and honor of family relationships, encouraging respect and care within families (Proverbs 17:6). It teaches the biblical virtue of honoring parents and legacy.

questions.question: What warning does Proverbs 17:13 give about responding to kindness with evil?
options: Whoso rewardeth evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.
The beginning of strife is as when one letteth out water.
He that hath a froward heart findeth no good.
He that covereth a transgression seeketh love.
questions.correctAnswer: Whoso rewardeth evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.
questions.explanation: This verse teaches that repaying kindness with harm leads to ongoing trouble, emphasizing the need for gratitude and integrity (Proverbs 17:13).

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 17 teaches that punishing the just and condemning princes for equity is pleasing to the Lord.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:15 states that justifying the wicked and condemning the just are abominations to the Lord, teaching the importance of justice and fairness in judgment.

questions.question: A believer wants to be more understanding and wise in speech. According to Proverbs 17, what behavior supports this goal?
options: He that hath knowledge spareth his words; and a man of understanding is of an excellent spirit.
A wicked doer giveth heed to false lips.
Whoso mocketh the poor reproacheth his Maker.
He loveth transgression that loveth strife.
questions.correctAnswer: He that hath knowledge spareth his words; and a man of understanding is of an excellent spirit.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:27 encourages restraint in speech and a calm spirit as marks of wisdom and understanding, a practical Christian discipline in communication.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:21, what is the emotional impact on a father who fathers a fool?
options: He doeth it to his sorrow and hath no joy.
He shall have part of the inheritance among brethren.
He is esteemed a man of understanding.
questions.correctAnswer: He doeth it to his sorrow and hath no joy.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:21 indicates the grief and sorrow experienced when raising a foolish son, teaching the importance of godly parenting and the consequences of folly.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 17:14 advise believers to handle the beginning of strife?
options: Leave off contention before it becomes serious, like stopping water from flowing out.
Justify the wicked to avoid conflict.
Exalt your gate to seek destruction.
questions.correctAnswer: Leave off contention before it becomes serious, like stopping water from flowing out.
questions.explanation: This verse teaches that early intervention to stop disputes can prevent greater conflict, encouraging peacemaking and humility (Proverbs 17:14).

hard.title: Proverbs Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Proverbs Chapter 17.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:3, what analogy is used to describe how the LORD tests the hearts of men?
options: The fining pot for silver and the furnace for gold
The plowing of a field before planting
The sharpening of a sword in battle
The weaving of cloth on a loom
questions.correctAnswer: The fining pot for silver and the furnace for gold
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:3 states that just as silver and gold are refined by fire, the LORD tests the hearts of men similarly.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:1 suggest is better than a house full of sacrifices with strife?
questions.explanation: The verse values peace and contentment over abundance accompanied by conflict.

questions.question: In Proverbs 17:6, what is described as the crown of old men?
questions.explanation: This verse shows the importance of legacy and family honor in ancient Near Eastern culture.

questions.question: Which figure does Proverbs 17:12 compare a fool to, emphasizing the danger of folly?
options: A bear robbed of her whelps
questions.correctAnswer: A bear robbed of her whelps
questions.explanation: The verse uses a vivid metaphor of a protective and dangerous mother bear to illustrate the peril of engaging with a fool.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:9 say about the one who covers a transgression?
questions.explanation: Covering faults fosters love and reconciliation, contrasting with exposing faults which separates friends.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:15, what is an abomination to the LORD?
options: Justifying the wicked and condemning the just
Offering sacrifices with a pure heart
questions.correctAnswer: Justifying the wicked and condemning the just
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes divine justice and the abhorrence of perverting it.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Proverbs 17:14 where strife is compared to letting out water?
questions.explanation: The verse uses a simile comparing the start of strife to the release of water to highlight its uncontrollable nature.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:22 say a merry heart does, according to the text?
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the health-giving and restorative power of joy and gladness.

questions.question: Proverbs 17:28 states that even a fool is counted wise under what condition?
questions.explanation: The verse teaches the virtue of silence and restraint as marks of wisdom.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 17:17 teaches that a brother is born for prosperity and celebrations.
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:17 says a brother is born for adversity, highlighting familial support in hardship.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'a man of understanding is of an excellent spirit' in Proverbs 17:27 within the cultural context of ancient Israel?
options: It emphasizes the value of self-control and wisdom as signs of noble character.
It praises physical strength as the ultimate virtue.
It suggests that wealth is the truest sign of excellence.
It indicates that silence is a sign of fear.
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the value of self-control and wisdom as signs of noble character.
questions.explanation: In ancient Israelite culture, wisdom and self-restraint were highly esteemed virtues reflecting inner nobility.

questions.question: Which theme in Proverbs 17 is foreshadowed by the statement in verse 23 about a wicked man taking a gift to pervert judgment?
questions.explanation: Verse 23 highlights bribery and perversion of justice, a theme echoed throughout biblical prophetic literature.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 17:24 contrast the eyes of a fool with the wisdom of one who has understanding?
options: Wisdom is near, but the fool’s eyes are on the ends of the earth
Both seek treasures in distant lands
The fool sees clearly, but the wise are blind
Both are equally wise in their ways
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom is near, but the fool’s eyes are on the ends of the earth
questions.explanation: The verse contrasts practical, immediate wisdom with futile, distracted pursuit by fools.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage reflects the principle found in Proverbs 17:9 about covering transgressions to maintain love?
options: James 5:20 - 'He who turns a sinner from the error of his way will save his soul from death'
Matthew 5:44 - 'Love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you'
Romans 13:1 - 'Let every person be subject to the governing authorities'
1 Corinthians 13:4 - 'Love is patient, love is kind'
questions.correctAnswer: James 5:20 - 'He who turns a sinner from the error of his way will save his soul from death'
questions.explanation: James emphasizes restoration and love through forgiving and covering faults, paralleling Proverbs 17:9.

questions.question: Proverbs 17:2 highlights a servant ruling over a son who causes shame. How does this reflect the social and familial structures of ancient Israel?
options: It illustrates that wisdom and responsibility could elevate a servant above biological sons in inheritance matters.
It indicates that servants had no rights in the family.
It suggests that sons always inherited everything regardless of behavior.
It promotes rebellion against family authority.
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates that wisdom and responsibility could elevate a servant above biological sons in inheritance matters.
questions.explanation: This reflects ancient Near Eastern values where virtue and wisdom could supersede birthright in family leadership.

theological.title: Proverbs Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Proverbs Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:3, what does the LORD do in relation to the hearts of people?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:3 states that the LORD tests or tries the hearts, showing God's attribute of omniscient judgment and holiness. Similarly, 1 Samuel 16:7 emphasizes God looks at the heart, Jeremiah 17:10 speaks of God searching the heart, Psalm 7:9 mentions God testing the hearts and reins, and Hebrews 4:12 shows the word of God discerning the thoughts and intents of the heart.

questions.question: What is said in Proverbs 17:1 to be better than a house full of sacrifices with strife?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:1 teaches that peace and contentment, even with little, are better than abundance accompanied by conflict, reflecting the biblical principle of valuing peace (Romans 12:18, Matthew 5:9). Hebrews 12:14 stresses the pursuit of peace, and James 3:18 highlights the fruit of righteousness being sown in peace.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:9 say about one who covers a transgression?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:9 emphasizes that covering sin fosters love and reconciliation, aligning with biblical teaching on forgiveness and mercy (Colossians 3:13, Ephesians 4:32, James 5:16, Matthew 18:21-22). This underscores the importance of love over judgment within the community of believers.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:10, whose reproof enters more deeply?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:10 teaches that a wise person values correction more than physical punishment, reflecting biblical wisdom about humility and learning from discipline (Proverbs 9:9, Hebrews 12:5-11, Psalm 94:12, Proverbs 15:31). This highlights the virtue of wisdom in accepting correction.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:17 say about the nature of a friend?
options: A friend loveth at all times
A friend is only for good times
A friend is born for prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: A friend loveth at all times
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:17 affirms the steadfast love of true friendship, which is constant regardless of circumstances. This reflects biblical teaching on love and brotherhood (John 15:13, Ecclesiastes 4:9-10, Romans 12:10, 1 Corinthians 13:7). True friendship mirrors God's faithful love for His people.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:22 say about a merry heart?
options: It doeth good like a medicine
questions.correctAnswer: It doeth good like a medicine
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:22 teaches that a joyful heart has healing power, consistent with biblical affirmations of joy and health (Psalm 30:5, Nehemiah 8:10, Philippians 4:4, John 15:11). Joy is a fruit of the Spirit (Galatians 5:22) and promotes spiritual and physical well-being.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:15, what is the LORD's view of justifying the wicked and condemning the just?
options: Both are abomination to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Both are abomination to the LORD
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:15 condemns injustice, affirming God's perfect justice. This is consistent with passages such as Isaiah 5:23, Psalm 37:28, Deuteronomy 25:1, and Romans 12:19, which emphasize that God detests perversion of justice and will judge rightly.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:6 describe as the crown of old men?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:6 depicts grandchildren as a crown to the elderly, highlighting the blessing of legacy and family. This aligns with Psalm 128:6, Genesis 48:9, Psalm 103:17-18, and 2 Timothy 1:5 emphasizing the value of godly descendants and familial blessing.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:7 say about excellent speech?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:7 teaches that wise and excellent speech is not fitting for fools, reflecting biblical emphasis on the power and responsibility of words (James 3:1-12, Ephesians 4:29, Proverbs 10:19, Colossians 4:6). Speech reveals character and wisdom.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:23, what does a wicked man do with a gift?
options: Takes it to pervert the ways of judgment
Uses it to help the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Takes it to pervert the ways of judgment
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:23 condemns bribery and corruption, showing how wickedness perverts justice. This teaching is consistent with Exodus 23:8, Deuteronomy 16:19, Isaiah 1:23, and Micah 6:11, which all denounce bribery and corruption as abominations before God.

questions.question: What warning is given in Proverbs 17:14 about the beginning of strife?
options: It is like letting out water and should be stopped early
It brings great blessing if pursued
It is easy to resolve once it starts
questions.correctAnswer: It is like letting out water and should be stopped early
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:14 advises that strife, once begun, is difficult to control, like water escaping. This aligns with James 3:16, Proverbs 20:3, Romans 12:18, and Matthew 5:9, all encouraging believers to pursue peace and avoid contentiousness.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:24 say about wisdom and fools?
options: Wisdom is before him that hath understanding; but the eyes of a fool are in the ends of the earth
Fools have greater wisdom than the learned
Wisdom and fools are equally blind
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom is before him that hath understanding; but the eyes of a fool are in the ends of the earth
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:24 contrasts the insight of the understanding with the foolishness of distraction. This theme appears in Proverbs 1:7, Ecclesiastes 7:12, Psalm 119:130, and Matthew 7:24-27, emphasizing the value of wisdom and the folly of ignoring it.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:12 compare to meeting a fool in his folly?
options: Meeting a bear robbed of her whelps
Meeting a lion in the jungle
questions.correctAnswer: Meeting a bear robbed of her whelps
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:12 uses the image of a fierce bear to illustrate the danger of a fool's folly. This metaphor corresponds with biblical warnings about fools and danger in Psalm 58:6, Ecclesiastes 10:1, Hosea 7:4, and 2 Peter 2:22, emphasizing the harm caused by foolishness.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 17:13, what happens to one who rewards evil for good?
options: Evil shall not depart from his house
questions.correctAnswer: Evil shall not depart from his house
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:13 warns that repaying evil for good results in persistent evil, consistent with biblical teaching on sowing and reaping (Galatians 6:7, Romans 12:17-21, Matthew 5:44, Luke 6:27-28). This highlights the principle of righteous retribution.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 17:28 say about a fool who holds his peace?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 17:28 shows that silence can be perceived as wisdom even in a fool, emphasizing the power of restraint. This aligns with Ecclesiastes 3:7, James 1:19, Psalm 141:3, and Proverbs 10:19, all valuing measured speech.
